segments.key_quote: Suta Goswami said, O learned Brahmanas, Maharaj Pariksit then began to rule over the world as a great devotee of the Lord under the instructions of the best of the twice-born Brahmanas.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the new chapter about Pariksit Maharaj and explains how he ruled as a devotee, guided by Brahmanas, and possessing qualities foretold at his birth.
segments.transcript: In this session, we will be discussing the importance from the first verse of the 16th chapter of the first canto of Shri Madbhagavatam. This is a new chapter we are beginning in this session. The chapter is entitled, "How Pariksit Received the Age of Kali." So, in the previous chapter, we heard that the Pandavas retired timely. They handed over charge of ruling the world to Yudhishthira, who handed over charge to Pariksit Maharaj, the only surviving descendant of the Pandavas. And now, how did Pariksit rule? That is going to be described in this chapter. So the first verse: sutavvaca tata pariksit vijavariya shikshaya mahi mahabhagavata shashasaha yatha hi sutyam abhijatko vidaha samadhisan vipra mahagunas tatha. The meaning of this verse is: Suta Goswami said, remember Suta Goswami is speaking to the sages of Naimisharanya. They are asking different questions and Suta Goswami is replying to them. So, he is describing how Pariksit Maharaj began to rule. Suta Goswami said, O learned Brahmanas, Maharaj Pariksit then began to rule over the world as a great devotee of the Lord under the instructions of the best of the twice-born Brahmanas. He ruled by those great qualities which were foretold by expert astrologers

segments.key_quote: Simply one has to become a devotee of the Supreme Lord then naturally automatically very easily one develops all the good qualities gradually while practicing bhakti
segments.summary: The speaker explains that good qualities develop naturally through devotion to Krishna and stresses the importance of preaching Krishna consciousness for world peace.

He naturally had all good qualities, but being a first-class devotee, Mahabhagavata, Mahi mahabhagavata shahrhah, so Pariksit is described in the verse as Mahabhagava, first-class devotee, the topmost devotee, the pure devotee. So pure devotee, his specialty is that he is himself got all the good qualities that are we found in a devotee and then he is well versed in the science of devotion and therefore, such a first class pure devotee of the Lord is able to convert others to become devotees by his transcendental instructions. His instructions are very, very effective, very practical, very powerful. They impact the heart. segments.key_quote: The state would get the best advice without expenditure.
segments.summary: The speaker describes the council of advisors of kings like Pariksit, consisting of great sages and Brahmanas who provided selfless advice without expecting salaries, highlighting the benefits of the Vedic system.
segments.transcript: No defect, no mistake, no limitation of time or place. Kings like Maharaj Pariksit had their council of advisors. Kings like Maharaj Pariksit had their council of advisors. And all the members of that council were either great sages or brahmanas of the first order. So who constituted this council of advisors of Parikshit Maharaj? All great sages, liberated souls. They did not accept any salary, nor had they any need for such salaries. These brahmanas, they were not paid by the king. Unlike modern day advisors, the IAS officers or the council of ministers, everyone is paid. Of course they need to take some salary, because they don't have any other means of subsistence. But in the former times, the brahmanas would give advice, they would not accept any salary. The state would get the best advice without expenditure. You see, this is the wonderful system in the Vedic times. The state would get the best advice because they are the topmost people, intelligent people, well versed in chastity. And they would not charge any fees. They would not take any salary. So without any expenditure, the state is getting the best advice. Now these kings, they were themselves samadarshi, equal to everyone, both man and animal. Sorry, the brahmanas. They were equal to both man and animal. This is important in the modern context. They would not advise the king to give. They would not give protection to man and instruct him to kill the poor animals. That is not the way to run the state administration. That human beings, they deserve protection. But animals, they can be sent to the slaughterhouse.

segments.key_quote: They were all self-realized souls and they knew perfectly well how all living being in this state would be happy, both in this life and the next.
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts the superficial happiness of a 'fool's paradise' with the genuine happiness that self-realized souls can provide, ensuring well-being in both this life and the next.
segments.transcript: Now, such council members were not fools or representatives to compose a fool's paradise. What is a fool's paradise? A person who in ignorance thinks he is very happy and everything is fine, without being able to perceive potential trouble or impending danger. That's called a fool's paradise. So these brahmanas simply would not give instructions in such a way that, oh, everything is very nice. Everything is going on first class. No. There is no internal dwelling. They were all self-realized souls. And they knew perfectly well how all living being in this state would be happy, both in this life and the next. Both in this life and the next. People can be happy in this life, as well as in the next, in the future, also. They were not concerned with hedonistic philosophy of eat, drink, and be merry and enjoy. No. So they were actually able to give perfect advice, perfect instruction for everyone to be happy.
